summary: This document provides a detailed overview of Jeffrey Epstein's life, including his career as a financier, his criminal proceedings, and various allegations of sexual abuse. It outlines his connections to high-profile individuals and the legal ramifications of his actions, including his 2008 plea deal and subsequent civil lawsuits. The document highlights Epstein's wealth, philanthropic efforts, and the controversies surrounding his relationships with underage girls. This document discusses allegations against Jeffrey Epstein, particularly focusing on Virginia Roberts' claims of being trafficked and abused by Epstein and others, including Prince Andrew and Alan Dershowitz. It also mentions the involvement of Donald Trump as a witness in a case against Epstein and highlights various media reports and legal actions surrounding these allegations. This article discusses the rise and fall of Jeffrey Epstein, detailing his transition from a math teacher to a Wall Street investment banker and his subsequent legal troubles as a convicted sex offender. It highlights his connections with powerful figures, his wealth, and the allegations against him regarding a sexual abuse ring involving underage girls.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Epstein is the central figure in the document, detailing his career, wealth, and criminal activities.

persons.name: Alan C. Greenberg
persons.context: Greenberg is mentioned as a notable figure in Epstein's early career, having been one of his students' fathers.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.role: Founder and Chairman of The Limited
persons.context: Wexner is noted as a significant client of Epstein's financial firm and has a long-standing relationship with him.

persons.name: Donny Deutsch
persons.context: Deutsch is mentioned as one of the bidders for New York magazine alongside Epstein.

persons.name: Nelson Peltz
persons.context: Peltz is mentioned as a competitor in the bidding for New York magazine.

persons.name: Mortimer Zuckerman
persons.context: Zuckerman is noted as a partner with Epstein in financing Radar magazine.

persons.name: Harvey Weinstein
persons.context: Weinstein is mentioned as a competitor in the bidding for New York magazine.

persons.name: Bruce Wasserstein
persons.context: Wasserstein is noted as the winning bidder for New York magazine.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.role: Former President of the United States
persons.context: Clinton is listed among Epstein's powerful contacts, highlighting the breadth of Epstein's social network.

persons.name: Kevin Spacey
persons.context: Spacey is noted as one of Epstein's associates, further illustrating Epstein's connections to the entertainment industry.

persons.name: Chris Tucker
persons.context: Tucker is mentioned as having flown on Epstein's private jet.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Prince Andrew is referenced in connection with allegations against Epstein, with Buckingham Palace denying any impropriety.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts
persons.context: Alleged in a sworn affidavit that she was held as a sex slave by Epstein and trafficked to several individuals, including Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Gerald Lefkourt
persons.context: Lefkourt is mentioned as part of Epstein's defense team during his criminal proceedings.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Reportedly taking legal action over allegations made by Virginia Roberts and has denied having sex with her.

persons.name: Ken Starr
persons.context: Starr is mentioned as a later addition to Epstein's defense team.

persons.name: Christina Pryor
persons.context: Pryor is mentioned as having reviewed materials related to Epstein's case.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez

persons.name: Lisa Bloom
persons.context: Bloom is mentioned as a legal analyst discussing the credibility of claims against Epstein.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as a witness in a new case against Epstein and has been linked to allegations of sexual misconduct.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Epstein is portrayed as a once-powerful investment banker who became a convicted sex offender. His connections and wealth are discussed in detail.

persons.name: Les Wexner
persons.context: Wexner is mentioned as one of Epstein's clients, known for his connection to the Victoria's Secret chain.

persons.name: Naomi Campbell
persons.context: Campbell is mentioned as part of Epstein's social circle, emphasizing his relationships with celebrities.

persons.name: Sarah Ferguson
persons.context: Ferguson is mentioned regarding her past financial dealings with Epstein, which she later regretted.

connections.description: Wexner was a significant client of Epstein's financial firm.
Epstein and Zuckerman were equal partners in financing Radar magazine.
Prince Andrew is a longtime friend of Epstein and has been implicated in allegations against him.
Roberts is one of the alleged victims of Epstein's sexual abuse.
Dershowitz was part of Epstein's defense team during his criminal proceedings.
Lefkourt was part of Epstein's defense team during his criminal proceedings.
Starr was a later addition to Epstein's defense team.
Pryor is an FBI agent who reviewed materials related to Epstein's case.
Virginia Roberts alleges that Jeffrey Epstein trafficked her and abused her sexually.
Virginia Roberts claims she was trafficked to Prince Andrew and alleges sexual abuse.
Virginia Roberts has made allegations against Alan Dershowitz, who is taking legal action in response.
Donald Trump has known Jeffrey Epstein for many years and has described him as a 'terrific guy.'
Wexner is identified as one of Epstein's clients, indicating a financial relationship.
Clinton is mentioned as part of Epstein's network of powerful contacts.
Spacey is mentioned as part of Epstein's circle of associates.
Campbell is identified as one of Epstein's celebrity associates.
Prince Andrew's friendship with Epstein is noted, along with allegations against Epstein.
Ferguson is mentioned as Andrew's former wife, with past financial ties to Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Pleads Guilty
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to a single state charge of soliciting prostitution from minors and was sentenced to 18 months in prison.

events.title: Investigation Begins
events.description: A woman contacted police alleging her stepdaughter was taken to Epstein's mansion and paid for sexual acts, leading to an undercover investigation.

events.title: Probable Cause Affidavit Filed
events.description: Palm Beach police filed a probable cause affidavit recommending charges against Epstein for multiple counts of unlawful sex with minors.

events.title: Civil Lawsuits Filed
events.description: Multiple civil lawsuits were filed against Epstein by alleged victims seeking damages for sexual abuse.

events.title: Judge Rules on Virginia Roberts Case
events.description: Judge Kenneth Main ruled that allegations made by Virginia Roberts against Prince Andrew had no bearing on a lawsuit seeking to reopen Epstein's plea agreement.

events.title: Virginia Roberts' Allegations
events.description: Virginia Roberts alleges in a sworn affidavit that she was held as a sex slave by Epstein and trafficked to several individuals.

events.title: Donald Trump Called as Witness
events.description: Reports indicate that President Donald Trump was called as a witness in a new case against Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Arrested
events.description: Epstein was arrested after allegations surfaced regarding his solicitation of a minor for sex.

events.title: FBI Investigation
events.description: An FBI investigation was launched after multiple allegations of Epstein procuring young women.

events.title: Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein negotiated a plea deal, resulting in a guilty plea to a minor charge and a short prison sentence.

events.title: Ongoing Lawsuit
events.description: A lawsuit against the US government was filed by two of Epstein's alleged victims regarding the plea deal.

locations: Little Saint James, U.S. Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted in 2008 of soliciting an underage girl for prostitution and served 13 months in prison.
Epstein's financial firm managed assets for clients with over $1 billion in net worth.
He had connections with high-profile individuals, including politicians and celebrities.
Numerous civil lawsuits have been filed against Epstein by alleged victims, many of which were settled out of court.
Concerns have been raised about Epstein's philanthropic activities and the lack of transparency in his foundation.
Virginia Roberts alleged she was held as a sex slave by Epstein from 1999 to 2002.
Roberts claims she was trafficked to several individuals, including Prince Andrew and Alan Dershowitz.
Both Prince Andrew and Dershowitz deny the allegations made by Roberts.
Donald Trump was reported to have been called as a witness in a case against Epstein.
Roberts has claimed that Epstein may have been involved in a cover-up of the abuse.
Epstein was arrested in 2005 after allegations of soliciting a minor for sex.
He negotiated a plea deal in 2008, serving only 13 months of an 18-month sentence.
Epstein maintained a network of powerful contacts, including politicians and celebrities.
Allegations against Epstein include running a sexual abuse ring involving underage girls.
Prince Andrew's friendship with Epstein has been publicly scrutinized, with Buckingham Palace denying any wrongdoing.
